# The Sharp Eyes project

Pervasive country-wide video surveillance network by 2020.  

### Data Source: Video

### Useage
[Snoopy neighbors report to
police.](http://paper.people.com.cn/rmrb/html/2017-06/14/nw.D110000renmrb_20170614_4-19.htm)

[Convince boyfriend of human rights lawyer to break up with
her.](https://www.npr.org/2013/01/29/170469038/in-china-beware-a-camera-may-be-watching-you)

[provide much of the IRL side of the social credit
score](https://www.theatlantic.com/amp/article/552203/)

[monitor classrooms at Beijing's China University of
Politics](https://www.npr.org/2013/01/29/170469038/in-china-beware-a-camera-may-be-watching-you)

[False positives](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/world/wp/2018/01/07/feature/in-china-facial-recognition-is-sharp-end-of-a-drive-for-total-surveillance/?utm_term=.a33210fa93f0).

### Challenges
Mostly technical, there are fewer legal hurdles in China.

### Connection between government and tech
Facial recognition, deep learning, AI startups with researchers working to improve video data quality. 

 [Cloudwalk received funding from a city government.](https://www.yicaiglobal.com/news/chinese-ai-firm-cloudwalk-technology-pools-usd7575-million-series-b-funding)
 
> "Companies like SenseTime, Megvii and Cloudwalk provide the software that powers mobile apps allowing people to alter, “beautify” or transform their faces for fun."
